name: Hampi
fun_fact: Fun fact: Hampi was the capital of the mighty Vijayanagara Empire (1336-1565) and by 1500 was the world's second-largest city after Beijing with 500,000 people (0.1% of global population)! The empire was known for diamond trading in local markets with precious gemstones traded daily. After conquest in 1565, the city was pillaged for six months and abandoned, becoming a ghost town where wild animals roamed - until Colonel Alexander Greenlaw took the first photographs in 1856 using silver iodide on waxed paper (negatives discovered accidentally in 1980!). UNESCO declared it a World Heritage Site in 1986.

hero_dishes.name: Bisi Bele Bath
hero_dishes.description: Karnataka's signature dish - hot lentil rice with toor dal (pigeon peas), vegetables, and tamarind-based gravy infused with a special spice blend
hero_dishes.origin_story: Said to have originated in the Mysore Palace. The name literally translates from Kannada as 'Bisi' (hot), 'Bele' (lentils), 'Bath' (rice). Also known as Bisi Bele Huliyanna, this spicy and tangy preparation uses a special Bisi Bele Bath Powder made from grinding chili, cloves, cumin, chana (Bengal gram), cinnamon, coconut, urad dal, coriander seeds. It's tempered with South Indian spices and nuts for a comforting, wholesome one-pot meal.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Taste of Brahmins - this family-owned gem takes immense pride in serving authentic South Indian cuisine in a setting that captures Hampi's heritage. Also available at Gopi Guest House Restaurant by the river.

hero_dishes.name: Kosambari
hero_dishes.description: Traditional South Indian salad made with split raw moong dal, coconut shavings, asafoetida (hing), mustard seeds, and fragrant curry leaves
hero_dishes.origin_story: One of the most popular dishes on menus throughout Hampi. Originally prepared during Navratri as prasad (religious offering), it has become a staple in everyday local food. A typical Kannadiga meal includes kosambari as an essential accompaniment, representing Karnataka's fresh, wholesome vegetarian tradition.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional South Indian thali restaurants near Virupaksha Temple, including Bhavani Hotel and Sri Venkateswara Restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Badane Kaayi (Brinjal Curry)
hero_dishes.description: Mouth-watering, spice-filled eggplant curry, best served with hot rice
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Karnataka specialty showcasing the region's mastery of vegetable preparations. The dish uses locally-grown brinjal (eggplant) cooked with a complex blend of South Indian spices including curry leaves, tamarind, and coconut.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local restaurants throughout Hampi's northern side near the river, where the variety of cafes is better than the southern side

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Breakfast: Idli, Dosa, Vada, Puri
hero_dishes.description: Sponge-soft idli with ghee-splashed crispy dosas, continuing with thali for lunch
hero_dishes.origin_story: The foundation of South Indian cuisine, using rice and various lentils with spices including curry leaves, mustard seeds, tamarind. Coconut appears in many preparations. The vegetarian emphasis exists due to the many temples and Hampi's spiritual importance.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Thatched restaurants at Hampi bus stand offer 'Cheap & Best' steamy Idli breakfast with chai. When you walk down from Virupaksha Temple from the bus stand, either side has the best restaurants - Bhavani Hotel and Sri Venkateswara Restaurant.

hero_dishes.name: Ragi Mude
hero_dishes.description: Finger millet balls dipped in spicy sprout curry
hero_dishes.origin_story: A nutritious Karnataka specialty using ragi (finger millet), a traditional grain that thrives in the region's terrain. Reflects the austere yet nourishing diet that sustained the Vijayanagara Empire's massive population.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional thali meals served 12:00-3:00 PM at local restaurants near the temple complex

hero_dishes.name: Ellu Chutney (Sesame Seed Chutney)
hero_dishes.description: Delicious chutney made from sesame seeds, a popular accompaniment to South Indian dishes
hero_dishes.origin_story: One of the classic chutneys of Karnataka cuisine, using locally-available sesame seeds ground with spices. Part of the vibrant array of flavorful condiments that capture the essence of Karnataka's rich heritage.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served with breakfast items at Mango Tree Restaurant and Shanthi Restaurant along the riverside

signature_drinks.name: South Indian Filter Coffee (Filter Kaapi)
signature_drinks.description: Strong coffee made from freshly ground beans and chicory, brewed in traditional metal filter, mixed with hot frothy milk
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: An everyday beverage in Karnataka, served in a stainless steel tumbler cup and davara (small wide metal saucer). Legend says 16th-century Sufi saint Baba Budan smuggled seven green coffee beans from Yemen during hajj and planted them in Chandradrona Hills outside Bengaluru, beginning South Indian coffee cultivation. The brewing method involves two cylindrical compartments - upper with perforations for grounds, lower collecting the decoction. Drunk throughout the day, especially with breakfast and afternoon snacks.

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai
signature_drinks.description: Spiced tea made with black tea, milk, water, sugar, and spices like cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, pepper
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Integral part of daily life in India. In South India, masala chai is a daily ritual enjoyed morning and afternoon, often with light snacks. Street vendors and households take pride in their special blends and brewing methods. Extremely popular with visitors to Hampi's cafes.

signature_drinks.name: Neer Mor (Spiced Buttermilk)
signature_drinks.description: Refreshing buttermilk drink blended with spices and herbs like ginger, curry leaves, and green chillies
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Commonly consumed during summer for its cooling effects. Offered as prasadam (religious offering) in temples throughout Hampi. A traditional digestive aid after spicy meals.

signature_drinks.name: Fresh Juices and Smoothies
signature_drinks.description: Fresh tropical fruit juices and smoothies
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Available at riverside cafes like Laughing Buddha on Hippie Island (laid-back vibe where you can enjoy hearty breakfast and refreshing smoothies) and Gopi Guest House Restaurant with its lush garden setting

food_culture_notes: Hampi's cuisine is predominantly South Indian, rooted in Karnataka's culinary heritage - vegetarian due to temples and spiritual importance
Food uses rice, various lentils, spices (curry leaves, mustard seeds, tamarind), and coconut in many dishes
Breakfast served 7:00-10:00 AM (dosa, idli, vada, puri), lunch 12:00-3:00 PM (thali meals and rice dishes)
All restaurants concentrated in small markets on both sides of Tungabhadra River - northern side has more variety and better cafes
Focus on South Indian specialties for authentic and consistently delicious experience
Thali meals at Mango Tree cost Rs 30 ($0.40 USD), other dishes around Rs 60 ($0.80 USD)
New York Times listed Hampi as 2nd best place to visit in the world in 2019 (after Puerto Rico)

landmarks: Virupaksha Temple - continuous worship since 7th century, dedicated to Shiva
Vitthala Temple - most exquisitely ornate, with stone Garuda chariot (ratha)
Tungabhadra River winding through boulder landscape
Granite boulder terrain - austere, grandiose landscape
Grand bazaar streets from Vijayanagara Empire era
atmosphere: UNESCO World Heritage Site (1986) with ancient temple complex
Former capital of mighty Vijayanagara Empire (1336-1565)
Spiritual pilgrimage site with continuous temple worship
Backpacker paradise with riverside cafes and laid-back vibes
Austere granite boulder landscape creating otherworldly scenery
Mix of ancient ruins and modern hippie culture (Hippie Island across river)
colors: Golden granite of ancient temples and boulders
Saffron and turmeric yellow of temple offerings
Deep green of Tungabhadra River and palm trees
White of fresh idli and dosa
Rust orange of Karnataka sunset over ruins
unique_modern: Predates Vijayanagara Empire - mentioned in Ramayana and Puranas as Pampa Devi Tirtha Kshetra
Primary historical settlement record goes back to 1st Century
By 1500: world's 2nd largest city (after Beijing), probably India's richest
Conquered by Deccan Muslim confederacy in 1565, pillaged for 6 months, then abandoned
Turned into ghost town with wild animals until rediscovery
First photographs: Colonel Alexander Greenlaw (1856) using silver iodide on waxed paper - negatives discovered accidentally in 1980
Stone-cutting technique: holes drilled, dry wooden pegs inserted, water poured - pegs expand and split stone
Chronicles by Persian and European (especially Portuguese) travellers describe prosperous city with diamond trading
Mango Tree Restaurant offers riverside dining surrounded by lush greenery - iconic Hampi experience
Laughing Buddha cafe on Hippie Island epitomizes laid-back traveler culture
